issues.title: IANA terminology
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
Please see
https://www.iana.org/help/protocol-registration

e.g.:

> Registry vs. subregistry
> You should almost always use the term "registry" to refer to a table or collection of assignments made for a common identifier type. The term "subregistry" should be reserved for registries that are nested within specific registrations. For example, at https://www.iana.org/assignments/isis-tlv-codepoints, "IS-IS Sub-TLVs for Reverse Metric TLV" is a subregistry for value 16 ("Reverse Metric") in the "IS-IS Top-Level TLV Codepoints" registry.
> 
> Registry group
> A set of registries presented as a single document through a common URL (i.e. https://iana.org/assignments/*) is called a "registry group." A group consists of one or more registries. Registries are typically grouped when they are thematically related, such as when implementers are likely to use the different identifier types for a common protocol.
> 
> In the past, these groups have been called "top-level registries" or "registries" (which we have now settled on as the descriptor for a discrete set of registrations, as above). [RFC 8126](https://www.iana.org/go/rfc8126) uses the term "registry grouping," but the RFC Editor recommended the more flexible "group."

issues.title: Expert review is incompatible with FCFS
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
@fpalombini's review:

I have reviewed it and I have one major comment, and I am pretty sure IANA will also complain if they get this as is: it is not ok to add criteria for IANA to check on a FCFS space. As https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8126#section-4.4 says:
 
    It is also important to understand that First Come First Served
    really has no filtering.  Essentially, any well-formed request is
    accepted.
 
What you are implicitly doing is re-defining a policy that is in practice Expert Review. So my suggestion is to change that range from FCFS to expert review, and specify that these criteria apply for an approval by the DE in that range (the criteria are different from the 0-255 range).

comments.author: thomas-fossati
thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> We should have a pair of terms like “expert quick review” and “deep expert review” to distinguish these with high visibility to the registrants.

@cabo, is this what you mean?

OLD:

| Range | Registration Procedures |
|--------|--------|
| 0-255	| Expert Review |
| 256-9999 | IETF Review or IESG Approval |
| 10000-64999 | First Come First Served |
| 65000-65535 | Experimental use (no operational use) |

NEW:

| Range | Registration Procedures |
|--------|--------|
| 0-255	| Expert Review |
| 256-9999 | IETF Review or IESG Approval |
| 10000-64999 | _**Lightweight**_ Expert Review |
| 65000-65535 | Experimental use (no operational use) |

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
On 2024-11-19, at 21:10, Thomas Fossati ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> Lightweight Expert Review

Yes.  How about 

Expert Review (Expert Check: FCFS+)

"Expert Review" points to Section 4.5 of 8126, so it is the official statement that IANA follows, and the parenthesis explains some more what procedure the expert follows.

The complement could be:

Expert Review (Full)

Grüße, Carsten

issues.title: notify IANAbis and ask review from IANA
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Note from @fpalombini:

* [ ] I think it is worth sending the doc to that wg [IANAbis] when it gets towards the latest stages.
* [x] It is also worth asking for an early review from IANA.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
Below is a (somewhat reworded & abbreviated) copy of the IANA review comments on -02:

1) Proposal to add a "Notes" column as below:

Range | Registration Procedure | Notes
0-255 | Expert Review
256-9999 | IETF Review or IESG Approval
10000-64999 | Expert Review | Lightweight review described in RFC XXXX, Section 5.2.1
65000-65535 | Experimental Use | No operational use

2) in Section 5.2.1, items 2 and 4 end with “… or IANA has approved its registration.” However, IANA isn’t the party that approves non-FCFS registrations. Media types are approved by either IESG-designated experts (vendor tree) or the IESG (standards tree, usually via the RFC publication process), while HTTP Content Codings require IETF Review (the IESG approves an IETF Stream I-D for publication as an RFC). In practical terms, if an expert approves a registration, IANA should add that entry to the registry within a day or two, and if the IESG approves a document for publication, 

“… must exist in the registration in the [X] registry” could be changed to “… must have been approved for registration in the [X] registry”

In practical terms, if an expert approves a registration, IANA should add that entry to the registry within a day or two, and if the IESG approves a document for publication,

issues.title: DE check 1 is unclear
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
We have the current text:

> 1. The content-type associated with the requested Content-Format must be associated with an already registered CoAP Content-Format;

What is intended with this?  The content-type entry must refer to an already-registered media type? 
(This is also in 2.)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> We have the current text:
> 
> > 1. The content-type associated with the requested Content-Format must be associated with an already registered CoAP Content-Format;
> 
> What is intended with this? The content-type entry must refer to an already-registered media type? (This is also in 2.)

Good catch!  It's a typo (missing "not" && missing "and content coding").  It should say:

> _"The combination of content-type and content coding for which the registration is requested must not be already present in the registry;"_

> usually via the RFC publication process), while HTTP Content Codings

issues.title: Potential new "bad" examples: duplication of an existing entry even though the fields are different?
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
I was thinking of a registration for an existing entry, where the strings look different but the content-format is effectively duplicating one that already exists.

Maybe cases like
1. Registration with a parameter having the default value "par=default", whereas the content-format without the "par=default" string was already registered.  Effectively they would be the same conent format with duplicate numbers then.
2. Someone registers with "Coding = identity" which is the default coding. This could duplicate an entry in which the "Coding" field is left empty.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: @thomas-fossati to have a look what you think.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Thanks, Esko.  They both look like good cases to add to our "What could possibly go wrong?" list.

The following note has been added to the registry:

> _"Note: The validity of the combination of Content Coding, Content Type and parameters is checked prior to assignment."_

This temporary bandaid should be removed when the new procedure is approved.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: I love the enigmatic, seemingly self-referential title of this issue :-)

issues.title: an optimisation for simple cases
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Amanda suggests two separate registration procedures for the 10000-64999 range: 

> _"One other thought about the FCFS range: if the registration consists entirely of a registered media type name in the “Content Type” field, with no parameter names in that field and no “Content Coding” entry, IANA can check for a corresponding media type registration (although it would be helpful to be explicitly told to do so, and to be able to refer to it in the registration procedure table). Maybe that could look something like this:"_

> Range | Registration Procedures | Note
> --|--|--
> 10000-64999 (no parameters or content coding) | FCFS | Corresponding media type registration required
> 10000-64999 (includes parameters and/or content coding) | Expert Review | Lightweight review described in RFC XXXX, Section 5.2.1

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: Seems ok - but it also needs to be checked by IANA that the media type is not already registered somewhere in the CF registry. If it is already registered (possibly with/without parameters, or with/without content coding) then it's again into the Expert Review bucket I think.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Seems ok - but it also needs to be checked by IANA that the media type is not already registered somewhere in the CF registry. If it is already registered (possibly with/without parameters, or with/without content coding) then it's again into the Expert Review bucket I think.

Yes, if there is any potential conflict with what's already in the registry, the procedure needs to move to Expert Review.

How can we express that concisely and understandably?

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
Maybe like this:

| Range                                    | Registration Procedure | Note                                                                 |
|------------------------------------------|--------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| 10000-64999 (no parameters and empty Content Coding)       | First Come First Served               | Corresponding media type registration required; and media type not yet used in this registry       |
| 10000-64999 (includes parameters and/or Content Coding) | Expert Review           | Lightweight review described in RFC XXXX, Section 5.2.1            |

issues.title: Add a Notes column to the registry

Split from #4 for easier tracking:

Amanda proposes to add a "Notes" column as below:

Range | Registration Procedure | Notes
-- | -- | --
0-255 | Expert Review
256-9999 | IETF Review or IESG Approval
10000-64999 | Expert Review | Lightweight review described in RFC XXXX, Section 5.2.1
65000-65535 | Experimental Use | No operational use

issues.title: Marco's WGLC review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/G4RdYYTcku3ss6Qg3hG-tLrJqnM/

```
[Abstract]

* Proposed rephrasing, in order to plainly state "this document updates that document":

OLD
This document updates the registration procedures ...

NEW
This document updates RFC7252 as to the registration procedures ...


[Section 1]

* Building on the previous comment and avoiding "memo", proposed rephrasing:

OLD
Section 5 of this memo updates the registration procedures ...

NEW
Through its Section 5, this document updates [RFC7252] by updating the registration procedures ...


[Section 3]

* Proposed rephrasing

OLD
... a CoAP Content-Format with identifier in the FCFS space (64999) that ...

NEW
... a CoAP Content-Format with identifier 64999 in the FCFS space that ...


[Section 3.5]

* Proposed rephrasing

OLD
... while this media type is already registered without that parameter.

NEW
... while a Content-Format ID 64900 is already registered for this media type without that parameter.


[Section 3.6]

* Proposed rephrasing

OLD
If accepted, this request would duplicate an entry where ...

NEW
If accepted, this request would duplicate an entry with Content-Format ID 64900 where ...


[Section 5]

* Please add a note to the RFC Editor about replacing "RFCthis" with the RFC number assigned to this document.

* For the portion that stays FCFS, the Note says

  > Corresponding media type registration required

  Maybe it's better to expand it along the lines of point 2 in Section 5.2, i.e.:

  > Corresponding media type must be registered (or approved for publication) in the "Media Types" registry [IANA.media-types]


[Nits]

* Section 1
- s/portion to reduce/portion, in order to reduce

* Section 2
- s/type" and "content/type", and "content

* Section 4
- s/This memo/This document

* Section 5.3

* Acknowledgments

issues.title: Add sentence to explain both quoted/non-quoted parameters can be registered in media type?
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
Example:

application/my; param="string1"
application/my; param=string1

We can say the preferred form is unquoted if it is allowed per RFC 9110.
E.g. for absolute URI/URN in parameter values, the quotes would be always needed.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
In addition, input from @cabo on the mailing list (2025-01-16) to get a canonical form of registrations: 

* preferred form is unquoted (when allowed by RFC 9110)
* semicolon followed by exactly 1 space

issues.title: Update 'erroneous' examples with parameter value equivalence cases (although string differs)
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
Example: 

```
application/my; uriparam="urn:foo:1"
application/my;uriparam="urn:foo:1"
application/my;uriparam="urn:FOO:1"
```

issues.title: Adding an "Associated Media Type" or similar field as registry column
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
(Idea that has been discussed with IANA & AD so far. Also to propose to WG.)

The idea is to add a new field/column, that shows the base media type that the C-F registration uses.
This type can be shown as clickable link to the IANA pages that define the template for each media type, such as e.g. these pages:

https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/application/pkcs7-mime
https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/application/vc+cose

The benefit is that having the field automatically ensures that the base media type exists.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Amanda's note:

> _"When a media type only appears in the Provisional Standard Media Type registry – which should be rare and temporary, and which I forgot can happen – I believe we would have to point to https://www.iana.org/assignments/provisional-standard-media-types itself. We’re not allowed to post registration templates for provisional registrations."_

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Email sent to the [core@](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/7VPASCA--UyTrWozOrTHJoahMfw/)

issues.title: Address "loophole" where DEs are not consulted in IETF stream
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
In the current draft the "lightweight" checks of 5.2 are only applied in the range 0-255 and FCFS range, not in the IETF/IESG stream review.

The DE is not consulted in the IETF/IESG stream; and there's no mention of anyone (e.g. IANA or DE) doing the 5.2 checks for this stream.

issues.title: Marco's shepherd's review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Archived-At: <https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/e7ISbZLSeqZy1Ow8aVkWDtg3K7c>

## Abstract

* [x] s/"CoAP Content-Formats" registry/"CoAP Content-Formats" IANA registry

* [x] s/"CoRE Parameters"/"Constrained RESTful Environments (CoRE) Parameters"

* [x] Even though the main contribution is the update to the registration procedures (per the document title), the abstract should also mention the new column added to the registry.

  Proposed new sentence at the end of the abstract:

  > Furthermore, this document adds a new column "Media Type" to the registry.

* [x] It says:

  > The affected registration procedures are specifically those regarding the IETF Review or IESG Approval portion of the registry as well as those regarding the First Come First Served (FCFS) portion of the registry.

  Actually, the new possibility to register temporary Content-Format identifiers concerns also the Expert Review portion of the original registry.

  Other than the Experimental use portion, all the other portions are affected by the updated registration procedures, although in different respects.

  As there is no portion to shortly highlight without going much more into detail, it feels like this sentence can simply be removed from the abstract.

  Putting together all the comments above, the new abstract can read:

  > This document updates RFC7252 regarding the registration procedures for the "CoAP Content-Formats" IANA registry, within the "Constrained RESTful Environments (CoRE) Parameters" registry group. Furthermore, this document adds a new column "Media Type" to the registry.


## Section 1

* [x] Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  the "CoAP Content-Formats" registry within the "CoRE Parameters" registry group

  NEW:
  the "CoAP Content-Formats" IANA registry within the "Constrained RESTful Environments (CoRE) Parameters" registry group

* [x] Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  This task is generally non-trivial, requiring knowledge from multiple documents and technologies, which is not a task to demand solely from the registrar.

  NEW:
  This task is generally non-trivial, requires knowledge from multiple documents and technologies, and is not to demand solely from the registrar.

* [x] Building on a previous comment about the abstract, the last paragraph in this section should take into account that: i) also the Expert Review portion is affected (by the possible registration of temporary Content-Format identifiers); and ii) a new column is added to the registry.

  Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  > In Section 5, this document updates [RFC7252] by modifying the registration procedures for the "CoAP Content-Formats" registry regarding its IETF Review or IESG Approval portion as well as its FCFS portion, to mitigate the risk of unintentional or malicious errors.

  NEW:
  > In Section 5, this document updates [RFC7252] by modifying the registration procedures for the "CoAP Content-Formats" registry, to mitigate the risk of unintentional or malicious errors. These updates amend the different portions of the registry, introduce a review procedure to be performed for most portions of the registry, and allow to registering temporary Content-Format identifiers for some portions of the registry. Furthermore, a new column "Media Type" is added to the registry.


## Section 3

* [x] Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  FCFS space that must

  NEW:
  FCFS portion of the "CoAP Content-Formats" registry, which must

* [x] Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  IETF Review or IESG Approval space.

  NEW:
  IETF Review or IESG Approval portion of the registry.


## Section 5

* [x] #41

* [ ] s/Includes parameters/Parameters included

* [ ] s/appears in this registry/appear in this registry

* [x] Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  requiring IETF Review with Expert Review or IESG Approval with Expert Review.

  NEW:
  requiring "IETF Review with Expert Review" or "IESG Approval with Expert Review".

* [x] s/will be Expert Review/is "Expert Review"

* [x] s/the checklist described/the procedure described

* [ ] It says:

  "A new column with the title "Note" has been added to the registry, which contains information about the expected review procedure."

  Why is this new column needed in the registry? Isn't it actually part of Table 8, as an amended overview of the registration procedures?

  For an entry added to the registry, it should be safe to assume that the right procedure associated with the range for the requested Content-Format ID was followed.

  Do you actually mean that the column "Note" has been added to the registration procedures, as shown in Table 8?


## Section 5.1

* [x] s/Or it may/Alternatively, it may

* [x] It says:

  "included in the IANA Provisional Standard Media Type Registry"

  Please add a reference to that registry, like in Section 5.2.

* [x] Proposed rephrasing:

  OLD:
  "TEMPORARY" in the corresponding registry entry

  NEW:
  "TEMPORARY", in the "Content Type" column of the corresponding registry entry

* [x] It says:

  "is included in the IANA Media Types registry"

  Please add a reference to that registry, like in Table 8.


## Section 5.2

* [x] s/can be placed directly/is placed directly

* [x] The second paragraph is not mentioning how the new column is updated in case a provisional media type is abandoned or made permanent.

  Suggestion to extend the second paragraph with the following new sentence:

  > If such a provisional media type is later abandoned or becomes permanent, IANA must update the "Media Type" field in the entries associated with that media type to be empty or to provide the hyperlink to registration information for that media type, respectively.

  (note the plural "entries", since multiple Content-Formats can be associated with the same media type, while differing as to media type parameters and/or content coding)


## Section 5.3

* [x] Point 2 of the checklist should also mention the case for the temporary registrations. Suggested rephrasing:

  OLD:
  The media type associated with the requested Content-Format must exist (or must have been approved for registration) in the "Media Types" registry [IANA.media-types];

  NEW:
  The media type associated with the requested Content-Format must exist (or must have been approved for registration) in the "Media Types" registry [IANA.media-types], or must be listed in the "Provisional Standard Media Type" registry [IANA.provisional-standard-media-types] (allowed only for Content-Format identifiers within the 0-255 and 256-9999 ranges);


## Section 5.4

* [x] s/the CoAP Content-Formats registry/the "CoAP Content-Formats" registry


## References

* [x] I think that the following references should be normative:

- [IANA.core-parameters]
- [IANA.http-parameters]
- [IANA.media-types]
- [IANA.provisional-standard-media-types]

* [x] Shouldn't RFC 9193 be a normative reference too?

* [x] As mentioned in Section 2 of the present document, some terms defined in Section 2 of RFC 9193 have to be understood as they are key terms used in the present document.


## Nits

* [x]  Section 1
--- s/For the (FCFS) portion/For the FCFS portion

* [x] Section 2
--- s/"content-type" and "content format"/"content-type", and "content format"

* [x] Section 5.1
--- s/requested by the authors/as requested by the authors
--- s/Internet Draft/Internet-Draft

* [x] Section 5.3
--- s/considerable code point/considerable codepoint

* [ ] Section 5.5
--- s/Type and parameters is/Type, and parameters is

* [x] Acknowledgments
--- s/suggestions and fixes/suggestions, and fixes

issues.title: Francesca's AD review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
I only have one comment, which I’d like to get your attention to, although it is definitely not a show-stopper, so please address it with any other Last Call comments – I will initiate the LC now.
 
In Section 5, you modify the CoAP Content-Formats registration procedure to the following:
 
```
   +------------------------+----------------+-------------------------+
   | 10000-64999 (No        | First Come     | The corresponding media |
   | parameters and empty   | First Served   | type must be registered |
   | Content Coding and     |                | (or approved for        |
   | media type not yet     |                | registration) in the    |
   | used in this           |                | "Media Types" registry  |
   | registry)              |                | [IANA.media-types]      |
   +------------------------+----------------+-------------------------+
   | 10000-64999            | Expert Review  | Review procedure        |
   | (Includes parameters   |                | described in RFCthis,   |
   | and/or Content         |                | Section 5.3             |
   | Coding and/or media    |                |                         |
   | type appears in this   |                |                         |
   | registry)              |                |                         |
   +------------------------+----------------+-------------------------+
``` 
 
I personally dislike how the same range is split in 2 rows. The name of the first column is “range”, any additional text should go into notes, in my opinion. I understand why you have written it this way, but let me try to propose a modification, that in my opinion keeps it consistent with how the other procedures are written (for example, 256-9999 also contains an OR of two registration policies.
 
``` 
   +------------------------+----------------+-------------------------+
   | 10000-64999            | Expert Review  | Review procedure        |
   |                        | or First Come  | described in RFCthis,   |
   |                        | First Served   | Section 5.3             |
   |                        |                |                         |
   |                        |                | FCFS is allowed if      |
   |                        |                | the registration has:   |
   |                        |                | * no parameters  and    |
   |                        |                | * empty Content Coding  |
   |                        |                | and                     |
   |                        |                | * media type not yet    |
   |                        |                | used in this registry   |
   |                        |                | and                     |
   |                        |                | * the corresponding     |
   |                        |                | media type registered   |
   |                        |                | (or approved for        |
   |                        |                | registration) in the    |
   |                        |                | "Media Types" registry  |
   |                        |                | [IANA.media-types]      |
   |                        |                |                         |
   |                        |                | Expert Review is        |
   |                        |                | required if the         |
   |                        |                | registration includes:  |
   |                        |                | * parameters and/or     |
   |                        |                | * Content Coding and/or |
   |                        |                | * media type appears    |
   |                        |                | in this registry        |
   +------------------------+----------------+-------------------------+
```
 
I know the notes becomes longer, but no text is actually added, just all condensed. Also, this is just a proposal, feel free to change as appropriate, but I hope you see my point.

issues.title: Christer's Gen-ART review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Archived-At: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/gen-art/VigOb1ZmMOENftHki83-v7hYwc4/

```
Nits/editorial comments:

It is a little confusing when the updates to RFC 7252 are in the IANA
Considerations section of the document. In addition, new procedures are added
in Sections 5.1 and 5.2, but those should be new 12.3 subsections in RFC 7252.

I suggest to have a dedicated "Updates to RFC 7252" section, where the text in
Sections 5.1 and Sections 5.2 are also added as new Sections 12.3.1 and
Sections 12.3.2 to RFC 7252.

For example:

----

4. Updates to RFC 7252

This Section updates Section 12.3, and adds the new Sections 12.3.1 and 12.3.2,
to [RFC7252].

4.1. Updates to Section 12.3

// The text in Section 5

4.2. New Section 12.3.1

// The text in Section 5.1

4.2. New Section 12.3.2

// The text in Section 5.2

----

The Security Considerations then become Section 5. The IANA Considerations
become Section 6, and there you only need to state something like:

"This document updates the IANA procedures of [RFC7252] for registering CoAP
Content-Formats."
```

issues.title: problematic `TEMPORARY` label
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
> _"[...] in Section 4.2, the authors make this request: "A temporary registration is marked by IANA with the label "TEMPORARY" in the corresponding registry entry." This is currently problematic for IANA.
> 
> _IANA Question --> Could this be changed to "A temporary registration is marked as such by IANA in the corresponding registry entry"? Changing "TEMPORARY" to lower case gives IANA the flexibility in how it visually designates and signifies temporary allocations."_

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: Right, it should be updated to say IANA can mark a registration temporary without saying how it does this visually. "Lower case" should not matter then.

issues.title: fix actions to perform on abandonment
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
> _"In the second paragraph of Section 4.3, the authors request that, "If a provisional media type is later abandoned or becomes a permanent media type, IANA must update the 'Media Type' field in the associated entries. In the case of abandonment, this field should be left empty.”_
> 
> _IANA Question --> In this specific case, wouldn't IANA be required to remove the Content-Format from the registry if there's no longer an associated media type?"_

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
The removal of an entry (e.g. because the provisional media type gets abandoned) would imply that the entry was temporary, because the media type wasn't permanent yet.  Is that right?

If so, this contradicts with our statement that we can't have temporary entries in the range 10000-64999.

This rule was (I think) added by me because of the following reason:
* if a registration is made in 10000-64999 pointing to a draft-v01 as the reference, and then the draft expires and is eventually abandoned, we still want the registration entry to stay.  Since the media type that the CF I-D is pointing to is still equally valid and the draft-v01 reference will still exist "forever" in the database.
* this is similar to making a registration by email or so.

The above first bullet can have a clash / confusion w.r.t. the text in our draft at end of 4.2:

> This may happen for example **when an Internet-Draft requesting a Content-Format ID is abandoned**, or when the referenced provisional media type is abandoned.

The first part in **bold** is only applicable in the Expert/IETF ranges, but not in 10000-64999.
To avoid potential confusion around this, it was simply said that temporary doesn't exist in 10000-64999. If we do allow it there, there could be a mistake by IANA that it removes entries in this range based on expired drafts.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
@EskoDijk thanks for the added context.

IIUC, we need to distinguish two “abandonement” situations:

| Condition | Action |
|----|----|
| A Content-Format becomes “unanchored” (i.e., the associated media type is abandoned) | Remove the entry |
| The I-D that requests registration in the 10000-64999 range has expired (but the underlying media type is alive and kicking) | Do not touch the entry |

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: However, in the context of this issue and the associated PR (#50), the “abandonment” we are talking about is the media type’s.  In such a case, it makes no sense to retain _any_ associated registration, whatever the range.  So the proposed change seems correct to me, at least in the context of that paragraph.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
@thomas-fossati Agree, that change seems correct.  I do think we need to combine that change with allowing "temporary" registrations also in the 10000-64999 range. 
In this case, an entry is not temporary because a registering document is still draft (or so), but it's temporary only if the Media Type itself is provisional.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
OK. Do you want to do this as part of #50 or separately?
Also, can you provide surgical prose?

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: @thomas-fossati  I can add a commit to #50 ! Since changes would need to edit some lines of text that are edited by #50.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> [@thomas-fossati](https://github.com/thomas-fossati) I can add a commit to [#50](https://github.com/core-wg/cf-reg-update/pull/50) ! Since changes would need to edit some lines of text that are edited by [#50](https://github.com/core-wg/cf-reg-update/pull/50).

Yes, please!

issues.title: Use of "FCFS" acronym in Table in 4.1
issues.author: EskoDijk
issues.body:
The table in 4.1 (Table 8) uses the acronym "FCFS", however, this may not be clear to a reader.

Because the table shown there is intended to exactly replace the table on this page:
https://www.iana.org/assignments/core-parameters/core-parameters.xhtml#content-formats

```
Range 		Registration Procedures 
0-255		Expert Review
256-9999		IETF Review or IESG Approval
10000-64999	First Come First Served
65000-65535	Experimental use (no operational use)
```

It adds the "Notes" column so the Notes text should be self-explanatory without needing to look up acronyms.

Proposal: write out the name FCFS in full.

Also, as another idea, could we simplify this text by just saying "Expert Review is required in all other cases" ??

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Wouldn’t it be sufficient to do something like: | Range | Registration Procedures | Notes | |--------|--------|--------| | … | … | … | | 10000-64999 | Expert Review or First Come First Served **(FCFS)** | Review procedure described in {{&SELF}}, {{checks}}.

FCFS ... |

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
@thomas-fossati Yes, that seems fine!

What do you think about "Expert Review is required in all other cases" - that would save quite some text.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> [@thomas-fossati](https://github.com/thomas-fossati) Yes, that seems fine!
> 
> What do you think about "Expert Review is required in all other cases" - that would save quite some text.

Seems like excellent "factoring-out” to me.  Where would you put it?

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: @thomas-fossati I can make a separate PR with this, then we can also check on the lists / with IANA if ok.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> @thomas-fossati I can make a separate PR with this, then we can also check on the lists / with IANA if ok.

please, go ahead!

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: See https://github.com/core-wg/cf-reg-update/pull/54

comments.body:
> […] we can also check on the lists / with IANA if ok.

The change in #54 seems rather uncontroversial to me.  Do you think it really needs extra WG/IANA eyes?

issues.title: "One Range, one Policy" instead of "One Range, Two conditional Policies"
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Med’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/a5xaEVG9TyY_vO8WjSxYeWjyC-w/)

> CURRENT:
>    The 10000-64999 range now has two separate registration procedures.
>    If the registration consists solely of a registered media type name
>    in the "Content Type" field, without any parameter names or “Content
>    Coding", and the media type has not yet been used in this registry,
>    then the policy is FCFS, as before.  In all other cases, the policy
>    is "Expert Review," following the procedure described in Section 4.4.
> 
> Given the size of the range, wouldn’t be simple for IANA to dedicate a range
> for “simple registrations” and another one for more complex ones?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
EskoDijk
comments.body:
@thomas-fossati I would actually be supportive of this idea of a separate range for "FCFS". This makes it clear where new entries purely handled by IANA would land -- currently they can land all over the range (see e.g. 20000 and 30000 allocations!) and I'd like to constrain that more.

Practically, the size of the range should not give problems because it may take many years or decades for the range to fill up. If we allocate the range 20001-29999 for example for FCFS. Today we have about 2188 media types in total so it provides space for all of them potentially, and more.

Nr 1.: guesswork it is, but based on current numbers and expectation. And I don't see problems ahead with that.
Nr 2.: this should not matter - it's only about review policy and not about the "structure" or "looks" of a Content Format registration. A user of any of the Content Formats typically doesn't care about what review it got.
Nr 3.: another argument in favor of splitting the ranges; we use currently number offsets in the following way: JSON is 50, JSON with deflate is 11050, JSON with zstd is 12050.  This would be possible in a better way with this proposal.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
If we don’t care about backward consistency, my main objection drops.

Re: sizing.  A 1:5 ratio (FCFS vs ExpertReview) may be a reasonable split.

issues.title: Abstract should be self-contained
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Med’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/a5xaEVG9TyY_vO8WjSxYeWjyC-w/)

```
OLD:
   This document updates RFC 7252 regarding the registration procedures
   for the "CoAP Content-Formats" IANA registry, within the "Constrained
   RESTful Environments (CoRE) Parameters" registry group.  This
   document also introduces a new column, "Media Type", to the registry.

NEW:
   This document updates RFC 7252 (The Constrained Application Protocol (CoAP))
   regarding the registration procedures^
                                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   for the "CoAP Content-Formats" IANA registry, within the "Constrained
   RESTful Environments (CoRE) Parameters" registry group.  This
   document also introduces a new column, "Media Type", to that registry.
                                                           ^^^^
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
This doesn’t seem an established practice, at least in the CoRE working group.

I’ve had a look at all of 7252’s updates:

* https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7959
* https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8613
* https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8974
* https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9175

They all just mention the RFC number.

issues.title: Example URI
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Med’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/a5xaEVG9TyY_vO8WjSxYeWjyC-w/)

```
CURRENT:
   In this example, the eat_profile parameter value (which can be any
   URI) is set as a Uniform Resource Name (URN) [RFC8141].  Since for
   URNs, the Namespace Identifier (foo in the example) is defined as
   case insensitive, the two registrations are semantically identical.

For consistency with other specs (rfc8407bis, for example), consider using
“example” instead of “foo”.
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Good suggestion.  [RFC 6963](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6963) defines `example` as a URN namespace that can be used in examples.

I wonder if rfc8407bis is not doing it right though — they use `example.com` rather than `example`.

issues.title: Virtual?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Med’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/a5xaEVG9TyY_vO8WjSxYeWjyC-w/)

```
CURRENT:
   This section updates Section 12.3 of [RFC7252] and introduces four
   new “virtual” subsections, 12.3.1 to 12.3.4.

These are not virtual but concrete additions to 7252. I suggest we delete that
mention.
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: The reasoning is that an existing RFC is read-only.  Therefore, the "actual" ToC of RFC7252 doesn't change as a result of this update.  However, its "virtual" ToC does.

comments.author: renzoe
comments.body: Hi, joining the conversation here from my other comment on Issue #74 . Thanks for the reply Thomas. I still believe that the "virtual" word confuses more than clarifies. (This is for the sake of constructive argument, Thomas/Authors do not read any harm in my words:) If the RFC7252 is read-only, how is it that we are updating it? "This section updates Section 12.3 of [RFC7252]" , so having said that we are indeed updating that section, we can add and remove things, and we are effectively adding text and subsections (subsections are part of the section, or you consider the subsection and its title as metadata? maybe that is why all this). In other words, I would not be shocked to say that we introduce new subsections within the Section 12.3 modifications. To be honest, before your comment I had not thought about the ToC (or a virtual ToC) of RFC7252. We could eventually say that our modifications also  update the ToC of RFC7252. What would happen if the section we are modifying had other subsections that now we are not including? For me it is a non-issue to think about the ToC of the original document. For the sake of openness, I think that even with the word "virtual" the reader understands  that we have new content for the Section 12.3 of RFC7252 (the title remains the same) and within the new content we have new subsections. So in the end the message passes, but to be honest I had no Idea why the new subsections were "virtual" (however, the content of the subsections is not virtual but "real"?) when I first read the document.  Anyway I think too much ink was spent for just one word. I can live on even if you decide to keep the phrase as it as it is , you can close the issue/s no problem from my side.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Already three reviewers - Christer, Med and you - have stumbled on _virtual_.

Even if I am happy with it (and the CoRE WG too), and I think it captures an interesting nuance of the RFC update process, I am happy to drop it if it becomes a source of confusion.

issues.title: More than one DE
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Med’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/a5xaEVG9TyY_vO8WjSxYeWjyC-w/)

```
OLD:
   The Designated Expert (DE) is instructed to perform the Expert
   Review, as described by the following checklist:

NEW:
   A Designated Expert (DE) is instructed to perform the Expert
   Review, as described by the following checklist:

More than one DE is usually appointed, while the OLD seems to assume that there
is one single DE.
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Not sure.

I read “designated expert” as “the expert selected for handling the registration request at hand.”  In this respect, I don’t think there’s more than one at a time.

Besides, using the indefinite article “_A_ Designated Expert” makes the choice unclear.

issues.title: Section 2
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Renzo’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/OX_G33Zs_1b5WaMiTWORNn3sul0/)
```
Lowercase terms seem ok (also used this way in RFC9193), except for
the “content-type” term that is defined and used as “Content-Type” in RFC9193.
Do we want all lowercase terms ? (This term in particular is used only once
later in the document). In any case, the passage
“term->term_rfc9193->definition” can be done unambiguously so not a problem.
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Happy to capitalise content-format as in RFC9193.  The hyphenation lowers the risk of ambiguity, but still.

issues.title: Section 3.3
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Renzo’s review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/OX_G33Zs_1b5WaMiTWORNn3sul0/)

```
How do we determine if a parameter’s value is valid ? (given an
existing media type parameter)? (We have to track the values on the “Reference”
column on the Media Type register? E.g., for “cose;cose-type=”, I could not
find it on IANA https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/application/cose ,
but have to read RFC9052). OK after reading the document, all these cases
(invalid or unknown stuff) will need an “Expert Review” . SUGGESTION: maybe put
a small disclaimer at the beginning of the section? For example: "Unknown or
Invalid values will be detected by a Expert Review".
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I am not sure I get the point Renzo is trying to make here.

§3.3 illustrates the difficulty in discerning whether a parameter is acceptable, which may require digging into some RFC, or worse.  IANA personnel's job description doesn’t include that - I think - which justifies moving to Expert Review.

comments.author: renzoe
comments.body: Hi, my suggestion was to make explicitly clear to the reader that to determine if a given request is invalid in those cases (either because foo is "invalid" or "unknown") already requieres an Expert Review. Or better, what is the definition of an "invalid request"? (In theory we do not have a definition, is ehe Expert Review that will determine if its invalid or not) In particular, 3.1 to 3.4, all are examples of something "invalid" or "unknown"... but how do you know that something is "invalid" or "unknown"? This is not hinted in the text.  My whole comment was to simply clarify to the reader that the only way to know if foo is unvalid or unknown is to dig into other RFCs (that may or may not be linked in the Registry). My whole comment because I was asking myself.. "how do you check if foo is invalid/unknown?" then I started digging. But maybe it is only me , and if its clear for all the people that already read this. No problem!

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
There are three possible readers and three possible paths/outcomes:
1. The person requesting the C-F:
  * They request what they need and let the process inform them if their request is acceptable
 
2. IANA personnel who need to decide whether to summon the expert:
  * They need to understand whether a request is to be forwarded to the expert, which is decided based on the established criteria (in case of parameters, they must summon the expert) 

3. The expert providing the expertise:
  * They are the experts and, by definition, they will magically know all the answers :-)

pulls.author: thomas-fossati

Fix typos and increase clarity in DE's check 1.

Fix #7

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Agree to add this. One remaining comment/question is that the current IANA registry policy description is more clear as it spells out "First Come First Served".

True that.

As a side note, after writing everything down, I'm beginning to think that the difference between "Expert Review (full)" and "Expert Review (Expert Check: FCFS+)," as suggested by @cabo, may not be significant enough to warrant different terms.

All the checks would equally apply to both ranges.  The only difference is that 0-255 requires the DE to judge the potential popularity of the requested C-F in constrained protocols, whilst 10000-64999 doesn't.

Is that worth introducing new semantics?  (Also, would we need to "Update: 8126" if we do that?)

We have a bug in our registration procedures, which has already been abused and can be abused again until we fix it.  If we bundle the fix with the wider IANAbis discussion, we risk delaying an urgent action.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
We are not updating 8126.
Both policies are Expert Review (Section 4.5) according to 8126.
They differ only in their DE instructions.

Expert Check/FCFS+ only has the well-formedness check; this could be done by machine if the media type registry had an API.
Full Review has that, as well as the DE looking at the registration and trying to understand it, e.g., if somebody registers a media type parameter set to 800 Hz, they might question whether that should be 8000 Hz instead.

Yes, the difference in DE instructions is somewhat subtle here, but we might have stronger differences later, e.g., in CoAP Option numbers.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
If you believe there is no need to update 8126, I trust your (superior) judgment.

Let's run this through IANA (#4) and see if they like the idea.

reviews.author: EskoDijk
reviews.body:
Agree to add this. One remaining comment/question is that the current IANA registry policy description is more clear as it spells out "First Come First Served".

In the future a visitor of the registry page will see "FCFS+" and may have no idea what this means. It's not a common abbreviation. So for the final text going into the IANA registry there's possibly a need to spell that out.  In the draft we can of course just use this term, it's properly defined.

comments.body:
Here it would be better to place the "(Full)" into the Note column. So something like:
| Expert Review | Full review

or 
| Expert Review | Full review described in [RFCthis], Section X

in case we have any description of what "full" review means. For example we have the sentence "the DE must also evaluate the requested codepoint concerning the limited availability of the 1-byte codepoint space." which is already describing a part of the "full" review.

```suggestion
The "lightweight" Designated Expert review checklist for the CoAP Content-Formats registry consists of the following steps:
```
I am fine with expanding here, but in the introduction, we have already defined DE as the abbreviation for Designated Expert.  What ambiguity would this change help to solve?

Ah, sorry I didn't explain the reason :)  it's to cater for the typical expected use cases where a reader jumps straight from the IANA registry note to the referenced section number and reads it, without reading the intro or rest of the document. Then it's good to not have to jump back through the document to find what "DE" means as it's an uncommon abbreviation. So it's to streamline the future reader's experience.
This is a very good point.  We have left "full" to the discretion of the DE, but it seems like a good idea to go the full mile.
@EskoDijk, please see if [0369f8e](https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-cf-reg-update/pull/17/commits/0369f8e1d93b08290cfd4e5bf55486d9f3f21106) works for you.
If needed, we can add more extra checks for "full" reviewers over "lightweight" ones.
Yes, that looks ok, thanks.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Yes I think it's going the wrong way.

ok!  let's not merge it yet then.

```suggestion
The 256-9999 range now has registration procedures requiring IETF Review with Expert Review or IESG Approval with Expert Review. In particular:
```

```suggestion
  BCP26:
    -: iana-cons
    =: RFC8126
```

```suggestion
* All assignments according to "IETF Review with Expert Review" are made on an "IETF Review" basis per {{Section 4.8 of -iana-cons}} with "Expert Review" additionally required per {{Section 4.5 of -iana-cons}}.
```

```suggestion
  RFC7120: iana-early
```

```suggestion
  The procedure for early IANA allocation of "standards track code points" defined in {{-iana-early}} also applies. When such a procedure is used, IANA will ask the Designated Expert(s) to approve the early allocation before registration. In addition, working group chairs are encouraged to consult the Expert(s) early during the process outlined in {{Section 3.1 of -iana-early}}.
```

```suggestion
* All assignments according to "IESG Approval with Expert Review" are made on an "IESG Approval" basis per {{Section 4.10 of -iana-cons}} with "Expert Review" additionally required per {{Section 4.5 of -iana-cons}}.
```

```suggestion
For the 256-9999 range and the 10000-64999 range, a similar criterion may also apply where combinations of media type parameters and content coding choices consume considerable code point space.
```
So, with this, I think this can go forward.

The changes above are admitting temporary registrations also for identifiers in the range 10000-64999, i.e., in all ranges, right?
ok with the change!
This rule is only intended for 0-9999!  E.g. if a draft registers ID 25000 and then the draft gets abandoned, but the media type is still alive, then the entry stays forever.
It's similar to a registration via email for example: it gets added, and maybe no-one will ever use it anymore, but still the ID remains forever as long as the media type exists.

I see, thanks! Then two things:

* "in the range 0-9999 does not" can instead be "in the 0-255 and 256-9999 ranges does not", since the registry shows those two as independent "ranges".

* Maybe it's better to include this explanation in a follow-up sentence, as a note that entries in the 10000-64999 range are going to stay (unless, as explained right below, they correspond to a provisional media type and this gets abandoned, at which point they are also removed).
We should clarify what we mean by _"pass its required review procedure”_

```suggestion
If a provisional media type becomes a permanent media type, IANA must update the "Media Type" field in the associated registry entries to ensure the hyperlink directs to the registration information for that media type.
```
Ok I can try an update for this!

I can try to clarify! We didn't define this before in the latest published draft.
It's basically the items listed under the column "Registration Procedures" so we could call it "registration procedure" and refer to section {{iana}}.

OK, we could say:

```suggestion
If a temporary registration in the range 0-9999 fails the registration procedure described in {{iana}}, IANA must remove the entry and set the Content-Format ID value back to "Unassigned".
```
done in last commit
done in last commit

done in last commit: it uses a note for the 10000-64999 range. This is just an explanatory note, since the reworded text that refers to "Registration procedure" already implicitly defines the normative part.
oops, missed your comment now - see the last commit for another text suggestion.

spurious “again” ?

```suggestion
If a temporary registration does not successfully complete the registration procedure, IANA must remove the entry and set the Content-Format ID value back to "Unassigned".
```
np! Yours looks good to me.

AFAIU, it’s a bit more intricate than that: early allocations are requested by WG chairs after the AD has approved the request made by the editors.

The easy way out is to put a full stop at “[…] action.” and drop the rest of the sentence.
Right; so maybe s/as requested by the authors of an Internet-Draft/as requested for an Internet-Draft

tiny grammar tweaks

```suggestion
Note that in the 10000-64999 range, the abandonment of a document requesting a Content-Format ID does not impact the decision to remove the entry or retain it.
That is because the required registration procedure for this range does not require the completion of any standards process or a registering document.
```

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: LGMT, modulo a couple of small editorial tweaks that I have inlined.

comments.body:
@thomas-fossati I think removing the "whether or not" just changed the semantics of the sentence! Now it sounds like the decision is always to remove the entry or that such decision is already being considered.

Actually, it is so that the abandonment of a document is not an event that triggers a removal decision. Nor does it trigger a "keep it" decision.

What about: "A temporary registration may be created for example by an IANA early allocation action, based on an Internet-Draft in the IETF stream."

This is just an example; so we don't exclude possible other ways or other types of documents.

YAP (yet another proposal):

> _"A temporary registration may be created for example by an IANA early allocation action {{-iana-early}}.”_

I don’t see the semantic change.

To my non-native English speaker ear _"whether or not”_ covers all the possibilities, therefore, is semantically redundant.

Well, there's multiple decisions that could be taking place:

1. decision to make to either remove an entry or leave the entry (not yet made)
2. decision to not remove an entry (already made)
3. decision to remove an entry (already made)

The original text indicates 1., which could after making the decision result in 2. or 3. While the removal of "whether or not" does immediately narrow the choices down to 3. only especially with the word "the" in front.
As in "the decision to remove the entry" -> decision is there, has been made already. Entry will be removed. As in "the decision to go on holiday in France".

About use of the / a :   just FYI, we should avoid deriving our semantics from such a small difference :) 
If you say "a decision to remove the entry" -> less certain; it's a decision in general that may come or may not come. Entry is only removed when such a decision does come.

Sorry for the (unnecessary) churn.
It has to do with the likely peculiar way I read this bizarre and foreign language :-)
To me “the decision to remove an entry” already contains all potential outcomes (remove it or leave it).
If it makes it clearer I am happy to leave the “whether or not” in.

(I will correct my inline suggestion.)
Ok, used this in the latest commit.

I found a formulation to work around this: see latest commit.
`Note that in the 10000-64999 range the abandonment of a document requesting a Content-Format ID does not cause an entry to be removed.`

@thomas-fossati Yep that language can be intricate: here's a similar case https://forum.wordreference.com/threads/decision-to-on.3202602/

So "decision on" is better if the outcome isn't known yet.

And here's the typical use of "decision to remove" : https://ludwig.guru/s/decision+to+remove 
when the outcome is known.
Fantastic references, thanks!

```suggestion
All the example registration requests use a CoAP Content-Format with identifier 64999 in the FCFS range of the "CoAP Content-Formats" registry.
```
maybe 'must'->'would' ?  But fine either way.

"would be denied" is what would not happen with the current (existing) rules; it would be accepted.
"must be denied" is what we would like to happen with the fixed procedure.

Maybe it's more clear if we write "that need to be denied, but would be approved by the present procedure" ?

Or the short version "that would need to be denied".  3 verbs in 6 words is maybe stretching the limit :)

My two cents:

> _”[...] that are invalid but would be approved under the current procedure.”_
@thomas-fossati That sounds good - I'll let you pick what to add!

pulls.title: Text simplification for procedures Table, adding a catch-all case
pulls.author: EskoDijk
pulls.body:
Aim is to shorten text (simplify) and also cover any remaining corner cases (if they exist).

Fix #53

comments.body:
```suggestion | 10000-64999 | Expert Review or First Come First Served (FCFS) | Review procedure described in {{&SELF}}, {{checks}}.

FCFS is allowed if the registration:
* has no parameters, and
* has an empty Content Coding, and
* the media type is not yet used in this registry, and
* the media type is registered (or approved for registration) in the "Media Types" registry {{IANA.media-types}}.

Expert Review is required in all other cases. | ```

reviews.author: thomas-fossati
reviews.body: LGTM.  (I have added the FCFS acronym in an inline suggestion.)

pulls.title: Explicit instructions for temp entry handling within the 0-255 range
pulls.author: thomas-fossati

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: @EskoDijk, are all your comments addressed? Can we merge and re-publish?

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body: @thomas-fossati Thanks, look ok to me!

Maybe change to singular "a Designated Expert can approve ..." ?
This makes it clear that a single expert can do so. Singular form is also used in the other changes below.

I think using the plural here is more correct.
It doesn’t designate a quorum of DEs, so there’s no risk of misinterpreting it for a requirement in such sense.
It just says that someone with the DE role has the power to approve temp registrations that are exempt from 7120-defined process.
Changing it to the singular would read like we allow a DE to exceptionally do that, which is not what we mean.


Maybe:

> _”As per {{&SELF}}, temporary registrations in the Expert Review range are approved by Designated Experts. These registrations are not subject to the formal {{-iana-early}} renewal process."_
I moved the note to the IANA considerations ([7de1743](https://github.com/core-wg/cf-reg-update/pull/56/commits/7de1743d10028a2ff6155846cdcf318d350ef727)), which is seems more fit.

If here too the intent is to refer to "someone with the DE role", then it should be:

> Instead, Designated Experts direct IANA to carry out this task.
Ok, if we use the same (plural) form on both cases it should be clear. (In the meaning of "any DE")

```suggestion
> "Note: As per {{&SELF}}, temporary registrations within the 0-255 range are approved by Designated Experts.
```
Would this be better? Since we have multiple ranges now with expert review.
